questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for Infectious Crystalline Keratopathy ( ICK ) except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Alcohol abuse is not a recognised direct risk factor for ICK, unlike local immunosuppressive conditions such as grafts, steroids, or contact lens wear.

  • ICK is a rare, indolent, slowly progressive stromal infection seen mostly in immunocompromised corneas.
  • It typically presents with branching, grey-white crystalline opacities in the stroma, often with minimal inflammation and an intact epithelium.
  • Common risk factors include:
    • Corneal grafts -especially with suture tracks (Option A)
    • Topical steroid use - causes local immunosuppression (Option B)
    • Contact lens wear -; particularly with epithelial compromise(Option C)
  • Streptococcus viridans is the most frequently implicated organism; it forms biofilms that resist antibiotic penetration.

Alcohol abuse, although a systemic immunosuppressant, does not locally predispose to ICK development.

Key Takeaway:

  • ICK typically occurs in immunocompromised corneas with minimal inflammation; alcohol abuse is not a recognised local risk factor.

questions.text: All of the following microbial organisms are implicated in development of ICK except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neisseria gonorrhoea is a highly virulent organism that can invade healthy corneal epithelium, unlike the low-virulence, opportunistic organisms that cause ICK.

  • Infectious Crystalline Keratopathy (ICK) is a slowly progressive stromal infection.
  • It typically occurs in patients with compromised corneal immunity (e.g., post-corneal graft, long-term corticosteroids, contact lens users).
  • It is caused by low-virulence, commensal organisms that enter via suture tracks or epithelial defects.
  • Common organisms include:
    • α Hemolytic Streptococcus (Option A)
    • Peptostreptococcus (Option B)
    • Candida (Option C)
    • Pseudomonas

Explanation of other options:

α Hemolytic Streptococcus (Option A): Known to cause ICK by forming stromal crystalline deposits.

Peptostreptococcus (Option B): Anaerobic commensal linked to ICK in immunosuppressed corneas.

Candida (Option D): Fungal organism implicated in several ICK cases, especially in graft patients.

Key Takeaway:

  • ICK is caused by low-virulence commensals in compromised corneas-Neisseria gonorrhoea is too virulent to be implicated.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male on long-term topical steroids after penetrating keratoplasty presents with painless, slowly progressive, branching stromal opacities in the cornea with minimal inflammation. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be confused with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Herpes Simplex Keratitis is usually associated with an epithelial dendritic ulcer, decreased corneal sensations, and active inflammation-features that are not seen in Infectious Crystalline Keratopathy (ICK), making it a less likely mimic.

  • ICK typically presents with:
    • Painless, slowly progressive stromal crystalline opacities
    • Minimal inflammation
    • Intact epithelium
    • History of steroid use or corneal graft
  • Differential diagnoses for crystalline deposits in the cornea include:
    • Schnyder Crystalline Dystrophy - Bilateral, central cholesterol/lipid deposition (Option B )
    • Cystinosis - Systemic metabolic disorder with cystine crystals in the cornea (Option C )
    • Lipid Keratopathy -Secondary to chronic neovascularisation or inflammation (Option A)

Key Takeaway:

  • Herpes simplex keratitis presents with classic epithelial lesions and is rarely confused with the crystalline stromal opacities seen in ICK.

questions.text: Which of the following infections is associated with loss of corneal sensations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) keratitis leads to reduced or absent corneal sensations, due to viral-induced damage to the sensory axons of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.
  • HSV epithelial keratitis presents with:
    • Dendritic ulcers with terminal bulbs
    • Minimal discomfort compared to the extent of the epithelial lesion
    • Significantly reduced or absent corneal sensitivity (hallmark)
  • This is in contrast to bacterial or fungal keratitis (e.g., Streptococcus, Candida, Pseudomonas), where corneal sensations are typically preserved, and ulcers are painful.
  • Loss of corneal sensations can also be seen in:
    • Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus
    • Diabetic neuropathy
    • Long-standing ulcers
    • Ocular surgeries (e.g., LASIK)
    • Tumours, Multiple sclerosis
    • Cocaine or NSAID toxicity
    • Leprosy

Explanation of other options:

Streptococcus (Option A): Causes painful ulcerative keratitis with intact corneal sensitivity.

Candida (Option C): Fungal keratitis presents with pain and stromal infiltrates; corneal sensations remain intact.

Pseudomonas (Option D): Rapidly progressive and painful corneal ulcers with intense inflammation, not associated with sensory loss.

Key Takeaway:

  • Loss of corneal sensation is a classic clinical feature of Herpes Simplex keratitis and helps distinguish it from bacterial or fungal infections.

questions.text: Which instrument is used to check for corneal sensations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Corneal sensations are best assessed using the Cochet-Bonnet aesthesiometer, a standardised device with a retractable nylon monofilament:

  • The instrument applies graduated pressure via a thin filament (extended from 60 mm down to 5 mm).
  • As the filament length decreases, pressure increases (from 11 mm/gm to 200 mm/gm).
  • The patient's threshold is determined by the shortest filament length they can perceive.
  • It provides a quantitative assessment of corneal nerve function and is used in:
    • Herpes simplex/zoster keratitis
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Neurotrophic keratitis
    • Post-LASIK corneal hypesthesia

A simple bedside alternative is touching the cornea with a wisp of cotton, looking for a blink reflex.

Explanation of other options:

Perkins Tonometer (Option A): Used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP), especially in supine patients.

Javal Schiotz Keratometer (Option C): Measures anterior corneal curvature for astigmatism assessment.

Pentacam (Option D): A rotating Scheimpflug camera system used for detailed corneal topography and pachymetry.

Key Takeaway:

  • Cochet-Bonnet aesthesiometer is the gold-standard instrument for quantitatively assessing corneal sensations.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with acute purulent conjunctivitis and severe hyperacute keratitis. On slit lamp examination, ulceration is observed despite an intact corneal epithelium. Which microorganism is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Some highly virulent organisms have the unique ability to penetrate an intact corneal epithelium, leading to rapid and aggressive keratitis. These include:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Listeria monocytogenes
  • Haemophilus aegyptius
  • Shigella species

Among these, Neisseria gonorrhoeae is particularly notorious for causing hyperacute purulent conjunctivitis and keratitis, with rapid progression to corneal ulceration and even perforation if untreated.

Explanation of other options:

Pseudomonas (Option B): Requires compromised epithelium; common in contact lens-related keratitis.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C): An Opportunistic pathogen that invades only damaged corneal epithelium

Pneumococcus (Option D): Causes corneal ulcers after trauma or epithelial defects, not through an intact cornea.

Key Takeaway:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is one of the few organisms that can breach the intact corneal epithelium and cause rapid ulceration.

questions.text: A 28-year-old contact lens user presents with acute eye pain, photophobia, and vision loss. Slit-lamp examination reveals a central corneal ulcer with stromal infiltration and the lesion shown below. What is the predominant cellular component of the reaction seen in the anterior
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture is consistent with microbial keratitis with hypopyon, most likely secondary to contact lens-related Pseudomonas infection. The hypopyon, seen as a layering of pus in the anterior chamber, is composed predominantly of polymorphonuclear neutrophils.

  • Bacterial toxins from the corneal ulcer diffuse into the anterior chamber.
  • These toxins stimulate acute inflammation of the iris and ciliary body, causing keratitis and uveitis.
  • Neutrophils migrate into the aqueous and settle inferiorly, forming a hypopyon.
  • This is a hallmark sign of severe infective keratitis, especially in high-virulence organisms like Pseudomonas.
  • Hypopyon indicates severe anterior segment inflammation.
  • It is gravity-dependent and shifts with head position.
  • It may also be seen in sterile keratitis (e.g. autoimmune peripheral ulcerative keratitis), but infective causes predominate.

Explanation of other options:

Red blood cells (Option A): Seen in hyphema, not hypopyon.

Platelets (Option C): Involved in clotting, not inflammatory exudate.

All of the above (Option D): Only neutrophils are present in the hypopyon.

Key Takeaway: Hypopyon in microbial keratitis is composed of neutrophils responding to anterior segment inflammation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer reports to OPD with complaints of redness, watering, pain and loss of vision in the affected eye since 3-4 days. History reveals trauma to the affected eye with a wooden stick on the farm while working. What is the most unlikely microbial organism to consider in this setting? Clinical imaging is depicted below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical setting suggests fungal keratitis, which commonly follows trauma with organic or vegetative matter, especially in rural or tropical regions.

  • Fungal keratitis is commonly caused by Fusarium, Aspergillus, and occasionally Candida.
  • Pseudomonas, although a major cause of bacterial keratitis, is more typically associated with contact lens wearers rather than vegetative trauma.
  • In this scenario of trauma with a wooden stick, fungal aetiology is more likely than Pseudomonas.
  • Clinical signs of fungal keratitis: dry-looking ulcer, feathery edges, satellite lesions.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with KOH mount, culture, or confocal microscopy.

Delayed diagnosis is common due to subtle symptoms and insidious progression.

Explanation of other options:

Aspergillus (Option A): Common filamentous fungus in soil and plants; a frequent cause

after trauma.

Candida (Option B): Less common but possible, especially in eyes with pre-existing disease or surgery.

Fusarium (Option D): Most common cause of post-vegetative trauma fungal keratitis in tropical climates.

Key Takeaway:

  • Pseudomonas is least likely in fungal keratitis following trauma with vegetative matter; filamentous fungi like Fusarium and Aspergillus are more typical.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of fungal keratitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fungal keratitis is characterised by active fungal invasion into the cornea and anterior chamber.

  • Hypopyon in fungal keratitis is not sterile because it contains fungal hyphae and inflammatory exudate.
  • The presence of a dry, gray-white ulcer with feathery borders, satellite lesions, and Wessely's ring (immune ring) is are classic feature supporting fungal aetiology.

Features of Fungal Keratitis:

  • Ulcer Characteristics: (Option A)
    • The ulcers have a dry appearance.
    • They have feathery borders.
    • Surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon:
    • If present, it is thick and immobile.
    • Hypopyon is due to direct invasion into the anterior chamber of fungal hyphae enmeshed in thick exudates.
  • Immune Ring (Wessely): (Option B)
    • The immune ring, also known as the Wessely ring, is a visible feature in fungal keratitis resulting from immune complexes and inflammatory cells depositing around the corneal ulcer. It indicates an immune response against the fungal infection.
  • Satellite Lesions: (Option D)
    • Satellite lesions in fungal keratitis refer to additional smaller ulcerations that appear near the primary corneal ulcer, indicating the spread of fungal infection in the surrounding corneal tissue.
  • Conjunctival and Ciliary Congestion:
    • There is marked ciliary and conjunctival congestion.
  • Symptoms:
    • Symptoms of pain, watering, and photophobia are present but are disproportionately less severe than those in cases of bacterial corneal ulcers.
  • Hypopyon Comparison:
    • In bacterial keratitis, hypopyon is produced by toxins, making it sterile.
    • In fungal keratitis, the hypopyon comprises fungal hyphae elements in exudation, making it unsterile.

Key Takeaway:

  • Unlike bacterial ulcers, the hypopyon in fungal keratitis is typically infectious and contains fungal elements, making it non-sterile.

choices.text: Topical antibiotics, cycloplegics, and tear supplements

questions.text: A 42-year-old farmer presents with pain, redness, watering, and blurred vision in the left eye for 4 days. Slit-lamp examination shows a central corneal ulcer with stromal infiltrates and mild anterior chamber reaction. What combination of therapeutic measures is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation: The management of an infective corneal ulcer involves:

  • Topical antibiotics: To eliminate causative pathogens.
  • Cycloplegics (e.g., atropine or homatropine): To relieve ciliary spasm and prevent synechiae formation.
  • Tear supplements: To promote epithelial healing and comfort.
  • Steroids are avoided in the initial phase of corneal ulcers due to the risk of worsening infection.
  • Corneal scraping for microbiological evaluation should ideally precede therapy.
  • Fortified antibiotics (cefazolin + tobramycin) or fluoroquinolone monotherapy are common empirical choices.
  • Cycloplegics reduce intraocular inflammation-related pain and photophobia.
  • Tear substitutes aid surface hydration and epithelial healing.

Explanation of other options:

Topical antibiotics and lubricants (Option A): While useful, this misses cycloplegics, which are essential for pain relief and preventing synechiae.

Oral antibiotics and lubricants (Option B): Oral antibiotics are not effective as first-line treatment in corneal ulcers; topical therapy achieves higher ocular concentrations.

Lubricants and steroid drops (Option D): Steroids are contraindicated in active corneal ulcer due to risk of exacerbating infection.

Key Takeaway:

  • Initial management of microbial corneal ulcer requires topical antibiotics, cycloplegics, and supportive tear therapy; steroids must be avoided initially.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer presents with redness, pain, watering, and diminished vision in the right eye for 4 days. He gives a history of trauma with a wooden stick while working in the fields. Slit-lamp examination reveals a central dry-looking ulcer with feathery margins. Ultrasound B-scan shows signs of vitreous opacities suggestive of endophthalmitis. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fungal keratitis following trauma with vegetative matter (e.g., wooden stick) is often caused by filamentous fungi like Aspergillus and Fusarium.

  • Topical antifungal therapy (e.g., natamycin, voriconazole) is first-line for anterior segment involvement.
  • Oral antifungal agents (e.g., voriconazole, fluconazole) are indicated in cases with suspected or proven endophthalmitis, scleral extension, or when the lesion is near the limbus.
  • Systemic antifungals ensure adequate penetration to the posterior segment, complementing local treatment.

Related Important Points:

  • Ultrasound B-scan is essential when corneal opacity prevents fundus view.
  • Systemic antifungals are required for posterior segment involvement.
  • Common fungi: Aspergillus, Fusarium, Candida.
  • Voriconazole has excellent ocular penetration and is effective against most filamentous fungi.

Explanation of other options:

Topical natamycin 5% drops alone (Option A): Effective for localised anterior fungal ulcers, but inadequate for endophthalmitis.

Intravitreal amphotericin B only (Option B): May be a useful adjunct in endophthalmitis, but not a standalone-topical and systemic antifungals are essential.

Oral steroids with antifungal cover (Option D): Steroids are contraindicated in active fungal infection and may worsen it, even with antifungal cover.

Key Takeaway:

  • In fungal keratitis with suspected endophthalmitis, combined systemic and topical antifungal therapy is essential for optimal management.

questions.text: All of the following agents can be used for chemical cauterisation except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

1% Sodium fluorescein is a diagnostic dye used to detect corneal epithelial defects, not a cauterising agent.

  • Chemical cauterisation is used to manage non-healing corneal ulcers by promoting debridement and antisepsis.
  • Agents like carbolic acid (100%) and trichloroacetic acid (10-20%) act both as caustics and antiseptics.
  • Povidone-iodine 5% serves as a milder antiseptic alternative when acids are contraindicated.
  • These agents help denature necrotic tissue and create an environment conducive to healing.
  • Sodium fluorescein, however, is used only for fluorescence staining of epithelial defects, not for treatment.
  • Cautery should be avoided in cases with excessive corneal thinning or perforation.
  • Contact of acid agents with the conjunctiva must be avoided to prevent symblepharon formation.
  • Sodium fluorescein stains denuded corneal epithelium and is visualised using cobalt blue light.

Explanation of other options:

100% Carbolic Acid (Option A): Penetrates deeper into tissue and acts as both an antiseptic and caustic agent.

5% Povidone Iodine (Option B): Used as a mild chemical cauterising and antiseptic agent.

10% Trichloroacetic Acid (Option C): Superficial caustic agent commonly employed in corneal debridement.

Key Takeaway:

  • Sodium fluorescein is used for diagnostic staining, not for chemical cauterisation of corneal ulcers.

questions.text: A 47-year-old patient presents to OPD with complaints of redness, pain and loss of vision for 2/3 days. Corneal ulceration is documented, and fortified antimicrobials are started. Post a heavy bout of sneezing, the patient reports to OPD with a gush of fluid coming from the eye and loss of pain. What has most likely happened?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sudden relief of pain with fluid discharge after forceful sneezing indicates perforation of a corneal ulcer.

  • Activities such as sneezing, coughing, or straining can cause a sudden spike in intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • A weakened ulcer bed may rupture under this pressure, resulting in corneal perforation.
  • This leads to aqueous humour leakage, causing a gush of fluid and immediate loss of pain due to decompression.
  • Following perforation, the iris and lens may move forward, and cicatrization is enhanced due to improved corneal nutrition from decreased IOP.
  • This is a well-known clinical presentation in advanced corneal ulcer cases nearing perforation.
  • Signs of impending perforation include severe thinning, descemetocele, and anterior chamber shallowing.
  • Perforation is an ophthalmic emergency and may require surgical intervention (e.g., tissue adhesive, therapeutic keratoplasty).
  • IOP drops sharply after perforation, which contributes to temporary pain relief.

Explanation of other options:

Ulcer has healed (Option A): Healing is gradual and not associated with a sudden gush of fluid or pain relief.

Patient has developed glaucoma (Option C): Glaucoma causes increased IOP and pain, unlikely with sudden pain relief.

Patient has developed cataract (Option D): Cataract develops gradually and does not cause fluid leakage or acute symptoms.

Key Takeaway: Sudden fluid discharge with pain relief in an ulcer patient suggests corneal perforation.

choices.text: Observation, decrease the IOP bandage and close monitoring

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient has been on treatment with fortified antimicrobials for corneal ulceration for a week. On follow-up visit, slit lamp imaging is as depicted. Iris tissue is seen plugging the perforation, and the anterior chamber appears formed. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In small perforations sealed by iris plugging, with a re-formed anterior chamber and stable pseudocornea, conservative management is preferred.

  • When aqueous escapes through a tiny perforation, the adjacent iris often plugs the defect, restoring anterior chamber depth.
  • This can result in the formation of a pseudocornea and adherent leucoma, leading to eventual healing without the need for surgical intervention.
  • If the iris seal is stable and the anterior chamber remains formed, observation with reduced IOP and protective measures (bandage, shield) is adequate.
  • Surgical options are reserved for progressive leakage or larger perforations.

Related Important Points:

  • Pseudocornea forms when fibrin and collagen lie over adherent iris tissue.
  • Observation is appropriate only if there is no aqueous leakage and the chamber remains stable.
  • IOP-lowering agents help reduce strain on the fragile pseudocornea during healing.
  • Frequent follow-up is essential to detect signs of decompensation.

Explanation of other options:

Sealing perforation with cyanoacrylate glue (Option B): Indicated if the anterior chamber collapses or the iris plug becomes unstable.

Performing keratoplasty (Option C): Reserved for large perforations or non-healing ulcers with risk of globe rupture.

Performing evisceration (Option D): Drastic measure for painful blind eye or endophthalmitis, not indicated in this case.

Key Takeaway:

  • In small sealed perforations with a re-formed anterior chamber, conservative observation is the preferred initial approach.

questions.text: Ocular involvement with Herpes Simplex can include which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HSV can affect multiple ocular structures, producing a wide range of presentations, including blepharitis, conjunctivitis, keratitis, and even anterior uveitis.

  • Blepharitis presents as grouped vesicles on the lid margins, often with crusting and ulceration.
  • Conjunctivitis is usually follicular, often with preauricular lymphadenopathy.
  • Keratitis is the most characteristic feature and may be:
    • Epithelial: dendritic or geographic ulcers
    • Stromal: necrotising or non-necrotising
    • Endothelial (disciform keratitis): immune-mediated

Related Important Points:

  • HSV keratitis is the leading cause of infectious corneal blindness in developed countries.
  • Recurrences are common and may be triggered by stress, fever, trauma, or immunosuppression.
  • Topical steroids must be avoided in epithelial keratitis as they worsen viral replication.

Key Takeaway:

  • Herpes Simplex Virus can cause blepharitis, conjunctivitis, and keratitis, making all options correct.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented to the OPD with conjunctival redness, itching and multiple vesicular lesions involving the eyelid on the same side. Clinical imaging is as shown. Identify the causative organism for the same
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vesicular eyelid lesions and follicular conjunctivitis in a child strongly indicate primary ocular HSV-1 infection, which is the most common form in this age group.

  • HSV-1 is the usual cause of infections above the waist, including the face, lips, and eyes.
  • Transmission is typically by droplet or direct contact in crowded, unhygienic settings.
  • Blepharitis and follicular conjunctivitis are characteristic early manifestations.
  • Corneal involvement may show dendritic ulcers and reduced corneal sensation.
  • Treatment includes topical acyclovir and supportive care; steroids are contraindicated in active epithelial disease.

Related Important Points:

  • HSV-1 establishes latency in the trigeminal ganglion and can reactivate due to fever, trauma, or UV exposure.
  • Vesicular eyelid lesions with dendritic epithelial ulcers and follicular conjunctivitis are typical features.
  • Fluorescein stains the bed of dendritic ulcers; rose Bengal highlights the ulcer margins.
  • Avoid steroids in epithelial disease; topical acyclovir 3% ointment or ganciclovir 0.15% gel is the mainstay.
  • Acyclovir prophylaxis may reduce recurrence in at-risk patients.

Explanation of other options:

Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (Option B): Primarily causes genital lesions; ocular involvement is rare and usually neonatal.

Varicella-Zoster Virus (Option C): Reactivates in older or immunocompromised individuals; presents with dermatomal vesicular rash.

Adenovirus (Option D): Causes epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, often bilateral, with follicles and preauricular lymphadenopathy but no vesicles.

Key Takeaway:

  • HSV-1 is the most common cause of primary ocular herpes in children, presenting with vesicular eyelid lesions and follicular conjunctivitis.

choices.text: Superficial Punctate Keratitis and erosions heal without sequelae
Dendritic ulcers end with a typical knobbed shape
Dendritic ulcers rapidly proceed to involve deeper layers of stroma
Dendritic ulcers show double staining: base with Sodium fluorescein and margins with Rose Bengal

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Herpes Simplex virus (HSV) Epithelial keratitis are true except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Dendritic ulcers caused by HSV remain superficial and do not extend into deeper stromal layers.
  • HSV epithelial keratitis typically begins as superficial punctate keratitis (SPK) or erosions, which heal without scarring. (Option A)
  • Dendritic ulcers are linear branching lesions with terminal knobs, characteristic of HSV infection. (Option B)
  • They stain with fluorescein at the base and rose bengal at the margins, due to virus-laden epithelial cells. (Option C)
  • Importantly, these ulcers do not penetrate the stroma; hence, the statement in option C is false.

Related Important Points:

  • HSV epithelial ulcers are the most common infectious cause of corneal disease in developed countries.
  • They often recur due to a latent virus in the trigeminal ganglion.
  • Topical steroids are contraindicated in epithelial keratitis due to the risk of worsening and corneal melting.
  • Dendritic ulcers are pathognomonic for HSV and require antiviral treatment (e.g., topical acyclovir 3%).

Key Takeaway:

  • Dendritic ulcers in HSV keratitis remain superficial and do not invade the corneal stroma.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not useful for the treatment of Epithelial HSV keratitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Topical corticosteroids are contraindicated in epithelial HSV keratitis due to the risk of worsening corneal ulceration.

  • Epithelial HSV keratitis involves active viral replication in superficial corneal layers.
  • First-line treatment includes topical antivirals like 3% acyclovir ointment, 1% trifluridine, and 5% idoxuridine, which inhibit viral DNA synthesis. (Option A, B , C)
  • Steroids suppress immune response, enhancing viral proliferation and converting dendritic ulcers into geographic ulcers-a serious complication.
  • Supportive measures include topical antibiotics (to prevent superinfection), lubricants, and cycloplegics.

Related Important Points:

  • HSV-1 is the most common cause of ocular HSV infections.
  • Topical steroids are only used in stromal or disciform keratitis, never in epithelial disease.
  • Epithelial ulcers show fluorescein staining at the base and rose bengal staining at the margins.
  • The recurrence rate of ocular HSV after one episode is ~10% at 1 year, 50% at 10 years.

Key Takeaway:

  • Topical steroids must be avoided in active HSV epithelial keratitis due to the risk of geographic ulcer formation.

questions.text: HSV stromal keratitis is driven by which mechanism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HSV stromal keratitis is an immune-complex mediated (Type III) hypersensitivity reaction.

  • In stromal keratitis (especially disciform type), viral antigens in the cornea trigger an Arthus-like immune response, resulting in deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the corneal stroma.
  • This immune-complex deposition leads to inflammation, stromal oedema, keratic precipitates, and potential scarring.
  • Unlike epithelial keratitis (active viral replication), stromal keratitis is immunologically mediated, often with no detectable replicating virus.

Related Important Points:

  • HSV keratitis has different forms: epithelial (active virus), stromal (immune-mediated), and endothelialitis.
  • Disciform keratitis presents with central stromal oedema, Descemet's folds, and Wessely's immune ring.
  • Treatment involves topical steroids with concurrent antiviral cover to suppress immune reaction while preventing viral reactivation.

Explanation of other options:

IgE-mediated hypersensitivity (Option A): Type I hypersensitivity, involved in allergies, not HSV keratitis.

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity (Option B): Type II; typically seen in autoimmune hemolytic anaemias and Goodpasture's-not relevant here.

Cytotoxic cell-mediated hypersensitivity (Option D): Type IV, seen in graft rejection and TB-does not play a major role in HSV stromal keratitis.

Key Takeaway:

  • HSV stromal keratitis is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction (immune complex-mediated), not due to direct viral replication.

questions.text: Which of the following is not implicated in the treatment of stromal keratitis in HSV?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CMC eye drops serve only a supportive role in epithelial keratitis and have no therapeutic role in HSV stromal keratitis.

  • HSV stromal keratitis is immune-mediated, primarily treated with topical corticosteroids to control inflammation.
  • Topical antivirals (e.g., acyclovir) are added concurrently to suppress potential viral replication and prevent worsening.
  • Cycloplegics such as atropine relieve ciliary spasm and prevent synechiae formation.
  • While CMC (0.5%) drops may be used for surface lubrication in epithelial disease, they do not contribute to the resolution of stromal immune keratitis.

Related Important Points:

  • Disciform keratitis presents with stromal oedema, keratic precipitates, and Wessely's immune ring.
  • HSV epithelial keratitis requires antivirals alone; steroids are contraindicated in that stage.
  • In stromal disease, antiviral + steroid + cycloplegic is the mainstay of therapy.

Explanation of other options:

Prednisolone acetate 1%(Option A): First-line to reduce immune-mediated stromal inflammation.

Acyclovir 3% ointment(Option B): Used alongside steroids to prevent reactivation of the virus.

Atropine 1%(Option C): A Cycloplegic agent used to reduce pain and prevent posterior synechiae.

choices.text: Stromal keratitis should be treated with a combination of topical antiviral plus topical steroid eye drops
Oral anti-viral Acyclovir may be added to topical anti-viral + steroid eye drops in patients with iridocyclitis
Low-dose oral acyclovir over prolonged periods helps reduce the chances of recurrence in prone individuals
Herpetic scarring cannot be treated by penetrating keratoplasty

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the treatment of HSV keratitis is false according to HEDS?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Penetrating keratoplasty (PK) is indicated in herpetic corneal scarring once the disease is quiescent for at least 6-12 months.

HEDS trial recommendations: Stromal keratitis responds better to topical corticosteroids combined with topical antivirals (e.g., trifluridine or acyclovir).

  • In HSV iridocyclitis, oral acyclovir may be added to topical antiviral and steroid therapy.
  • Long-term prophylaxis with oral acyclovir (400 mg twice daily) significantly reduces the frequency of recurrence in patients with recurrent herpetic keratitis.
  • PK is useful in visually significant scarring, provided there is no active infection and the eye is stable. Recurrence and graft rejection risks remain high in vascularized corneas.

Related Important Points:

  • HEDS did not find oral acyclovir beneficial in acute stromal keratitis unless iritis was present.
  • Stromal keratitis is immune-mediated and not due to active viral replication alone.
  • The HSV recurrence rate can be reduced by 40-50% with suppressive oral acyclovir.

Explanation of other options:

Topical steroid + antiviral for stromal keratitis (Option A): Supported by HEDS-I trial data.

Oral acyclovir in iridocyclitis (Option B): Beneficial as an adjunct to control inflammation and viral replication.

Low-dose oral acyclovir prophylaxis (Option C): Recommended in recurrent HSV keratitis.

choices.text: 400 mg 5 times a day, 6 months+
400 mg 2 times a day, 6 months+
800 mg 5 times a day, 6 months+
800 mg 2 times a day, 6 months+

questions.text: What is the recommended dosage of oral acyclovir for the prevention of recurrences of HSV keratitis in prone individuals according to HEDS?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HEDS-II trial concluded that oral Acyclovir 400 mg twice daily is effective in reducing the recurrence of herpetic eye disease in susceptible individuals.

  • HSV keratitis has a high recurrence rate, especially in patients with prior stromal involvement.
  • The HEDS Recurrence Prevention Trial showed that 400 mg BID of Acyclovir over 6 months to 1 year lowers the recurrence rate by nearly 50%.
  • This low-dose regimen strikes a balance between efficacy and long-term tolerability.
  • It is particularly useful in patients undergoing keratoplasty or with frequent recurrences.

Related Important Points:

  • Recurrence risk increases with each episode; prophylaxis is crucial in high-risk cases.
  • Long-term Acyclovir does not eliminate the virus but reduces flare-ups and corneal scarring.
  • HEDS also showed that oral Acyclovir is beneficial in HSV iridocyclitis when added to topical antivirals + steroids.

Explanation of other options:

400 mg five times/day (Option A): This is the dosing for acute treatment, not maintenance or prophylaxis.

800 mg five times/day (Option C): Used for severe initial or systemic HSV infections, not for prevention.

800 mg twice/day (Option D): Higher than needed for suppression; increases side effects without added benefit.

questions.text: Which virus is implicated in the development of Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO) is caused by reactivation of Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV), the same virus that causes chickenpox.

  • After primary infection, VZV remains latent in cranial nerve sensory ganglia.
  • Reactivation later in life, especially in elderly or immunosuppressed individuals, leads to shingles, and if the ophthalmic branch of CN V is involved, it presents as HZO.
  • Morphologically identical but antigenically distinct from HSV, VZV can lead to keratitis, uveitis, scleritis, and neurotrophic keratopathy in HZO.
  • A classic sign is Hutchinson's sign, vesicles on the tip/side of the nose, suggesting nasociliary nerve involvement and increased ocular complication risk.

Related Important Points:

  • HZO most often affects individuals in their 6th-7th decade of life.
  • Oral antivirals (Acyclovir 800 mg five times/day) reduce duration, severity, and risk of post-herpetic neuralgia.
  • In immunocompromised patients, the disease is more severe and often requires IV antivirals.
  • Vaccination against zoster reduces the risk of HZO significantly.

Explanation of other options:

Herpes Simplex Virus type-1 (Option A): Causes HSV keratitis but not HZO.

Herpes Simplex Virus type-2 (Option B): Associated more with genital herpes; not implicated in HZO.

Epstein-Barr Virus (Option D): Linked with infectious mononucleosis and lymphoproliferative disorders, not HZO.

questions.text: Which nerve ganglion is involved in the pathology of Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Gasserian (trigeminal) ganglion is the primary site of viral latency and reactivation in HZO.

  • After primary varicella infection, VZV travels retrograde to lie dormant in sensory ganglia.
  • In HZO, reactivation occurs in the Gasserian ganglion, specifically affecting the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve.
  • The virus then spreads anterograde along branches like the nasociliary nerve, leading to vesicular eruptions in its dermatome and ocular complications.

Related Important Points:

  • Hutchinson's sign indicates nasociliary nerve involvement and predicts ocular complications.
  • The Gasserian ganglion contains the cell bodies of sensory neurons for all three branches of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Ocular involvement includes keratitis, uveitis, episcleritis, and neurotrophic keratopathy.

Explanation of other options:

Ciliary ganglion (Option A): Parasympathetic relay for intraocular muscles, not involved in HZO.

Geniculate ganglion (Option C): Sensory ganglion of the facial nerve, implicated in Ramsay Hunt syndrome, not HZO.

Inferior cervical ganglion (Option D): Sympathetic chain ganglion, no role in HZO pathogenesis.

choices.text: Skin involvement is in the dermatome supplied by the first branch of the Trigeminal nerve
Skin involvement is in the dermatome supplied by the second branch of the Trigeminal
Involvement of the tip of the nose indicates Nasociliary branch involvement

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding disease involvement in this patient is correct? Clinical imaging is as depicted below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO) affects the dermatome of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve, and involvement of the nasal tip signals nasociliary nerve involvement.

  • The first (ophthalmic) division of the trigeminal nerve (V1) supplies the forehead, upper eyelid, and nose.
  • The nasociliary branch, a subdivision of V1, supplies the tip, side, and root of the nose.
  • Hutchinson's sign: presence of vesicles at the tip of the nose, strongly correlates with ocular involvement, like keratitis or uveitis.

Related Important Points:

  • The maxillary division (V2) supplies the midface, including the cheek, not affected here. (Option B ruled out)
  • Ocular complications are more likely if the nasociliary nerve is involved.
  • Prompt antiviral therapy can reduce the risk of post-herpetic neuralgia and ocular sequelae.

questions.text: What is the recommended dosage of Acyclovir for the treatment of Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The standard oral treatment of HZO is 800 mg Acyclovir five times a day for 7-10 days, ideally initiated within 72 hours of rash onset.

  • Early antiviral therapy shortens the duration of viral replication, accelerates healing of skin lesions, and reduces the incidence of post-herpetic neuralgia.
  • The optimal window for initiating therapy is within 72 hours of rash appearance.
  • Other oral antivirals like valacyclovir (1 g TID) or famciclovir (500 mg TID) are equally effective and better tolerated.

Related Important Points:

  • HZO typically affects older adults and immunocompromised individuals.
  • In severe cases or immunocompromised patients, IV acyclovir may be required.
  • Systemic steroids may be co-administered in moderate to severe cases, but only with antivirals.

Explanation of other options:

400 mg twice daily (Option A): This is the prophylactic dose used for HSV keratitis recurrence prevention, not suitable for acute HZO treatment.

400 mg five times daily (Option B): This regimen is used in HSV epithelial keratitis, but the dose is too low for HZO.

800 mg twice daily (Option C): This dose is subtherapeutic for HZO and insufficient to suppress active viral replication.

questions.text: What is the indication for the use of systemic steroids in the treatment of HZO?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Systemic corticosteroids are primarily indicated in HZO cases presenting with oculomotor nerve palsy or optic neuritis, typically due to occlusive vasculitis.

  • Corticosteroids are used only in combination with systemic antiviral therapy (e.g., acyclovir).
  • Initial dose: Prednisolone 60 mg/day, tapered over 10-14 days.
  • They help reduce neurological inflammation and hasten recovery from cranial nerve palsy.
  • Systemic steroids should not be used in isolation due to the risk of worsening viral replication.

Related Important Points:

  • HZO may involve various ocular and cranial nerve structures due to VZV reactivation in the Gasserian ganglion.
  • Cranial nerve palsies, particularly CN III (oculomotor), are serious complications and may respond to early steroid therapy.
  • Steroids are contraindicated in the absence of antiviral coverage due to risk of geographic ulcer formation.

Explanation of other options:

Keratouveitis (Option A): Managed with topical steroids, topical antibiotics, and oral antivirals, not an indication for systemic steroids.

Post-herpetic neuralgia (Option B): Treated with neuropathic pain agents (e.g., gabapentin, opioids); systemic steroids have no proven benefit.

Acute retinal necrosis (Option D): Requires systemic and intravitreal antiviral therapy; steroids may worsen viral replication and are avoided during active retinal infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of Acanthamoeba Keratitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trauma is not a typical risk factor for Acanthamoeba keratitis, which is more commonly associated with contact lens use and exposure to contaminated water.

  • Acanthamoeba is a free-living protozoan found in tap water, swimming pools, hot tubs, and soil.
  • Hence, swimming is a risk factor. (Option A)
  • Contact lens wearers are at the highest risk (Option B), particularly when:
    • Lenses are washed or stored in tap water
    • Lenses are worn while swimming(Option A)
    • There is poor hygiene or improper disinfection. (Option D)
  • Trauma is rarely associated and is not a predisposing factor unless combined with contaminated exposure.

Related Important Points:

  • Acanthamoeba keratitis is often misdiagnosed as HSV keratitis, especially in early stages.
  • A ring infiltrate and radial perineuritis are classic signs.
  • Diagnosis: Corneal scraping, culture on non-nutrient agar with E. coli overlay, confocal microscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following agents are used for the treatment of Acanthamoeba Keratitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acanthamoeba keratitis is best treated using a combination of anti-amoebic agents, including PHMB, propamidine, and chlorhexidine, especially in early stages.

  • PHMB (Polyhexamethylene biguanide) 0.02% and Propamidine isethionate 0.1% are first-line agents with good trophozoite and cysticidal action.
  • Chlorhexidine 0.02% has also shown efficacy and is often combined with PHMB for enhanced activity.
  • Early combination therapy leads to better outcomes and can prevent the need for surgical interventions.

Related Important Points:

  • Other agents used include neomycin 0.175%, clotrimazole 1%, miconazole 1%, and oral antifungals like ketoconazole or itraconazole in advanced cases.
  • Corneal debridement may improve drug penetration.
  • Late diagnosis often leads to poor prognosis, with the risk of perforation and may require keratoplasty.

choices.text: Sealing perforation with cyano-acrylate glue f/b Bandage Contact Lens (BCL)

questions.text: A 54 year old patient had been on treatment of fortified anti-microbials for corneal ulceration for a week. On follow-up visit, slit lamp imaging depicted corneal perforation with pseudo-cornea formation. Patient was advised observation and close monitoring. Now patient has developed flat anterior chamber. Size of perforation is approximately 1.5* 1.5 mm. What is next step of management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Small corneal perforations (<2 mm) with a flat anterior chamber require immediate sealing using cyanoacrylate glue, followed by BCL to restore globe integrity and prevent secondary complications.

  • For perforations ≤2 mm, N-butyl cyanoacrylate glue is applied after debridement to promote sealing.
  • Once the anterior chamber is reformed, a Bandage Contact Lens (BCL) is placed to protect the surface and enhance healing.
  • Larger perforations may require tectonic keratoplasty or patch grafting, depending on size and location. (Option C ruled out)
  • Observation alone is inappropriate for a flat anterior chamber, and evisceration is only considered in unsalvageable eyes. (Option A ruled out)

Related Important Points:

  • Cyanoacrylate glue is used for sealing small, non-self-healing corneal perforations.
  • Keratoplasty is reserved for perforations >3-4 mm or non-responding cases.
  • Tenonplasty is an alternative for peripheral perforations with tissue loss.
  • Evisceration is not considered unless there is panophthalmitis or a blinding, painful eye. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A young man aged 30 years presents with difficulty in vision in the left eye for the last 10 days. He is a rural community and has a history of trauma to his left eye with vegetative matter 10-15 days back. On examination, there is an ulcerative lesion in the infiltrate. Ulcer margin is feathery and hyphate. There are a few satellite lesions also. The most probable etiological agent is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A history of trauma with vegetative matter followed by a corneal ulcer with feathery margins and satellite lesions is highly suggestive of fungal keratitis, especially Fusarium.

  • Fusarium is the most common cause of filamentous fungal keratitis following trauma with organic matter.
  • Characteristic clinical features include:
    • Dry-looking ulcer
    • Feathery margins
    • Hyphate edges
    • Satellite lesions
  • It is more common in tropical climates and among agricultural workers.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by KOH mount, calcofluor white staining, and culture on Sabouraud's Dextrose Agar.
  • Treatment includes topical antifungals like natamycin 5% and possibly systemic antifungals in deep or non-responding cases.
  • Trauma with vegetative matter is a major risk factor for fungal keratitis.

Explanation of other options:

Acanthamoeba (Option A): Causes severe pain out of proportion to clinical signs, ring infiltrate, not associated with vegetative trauma.

Corynebacterium diphtheriae (Option B): Rare cause, may lead to pseudomembranous conjunctivitis, not fungal ulcer.

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option D): Produces a greyish ulcer with serpiginous margins, not feathery or hyphate.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male developed pain and redness in RE after a parotid tumour surgery on the same side. What can be the most likely diagnosis, seeing the picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Facial nerve palsy following parotid gland surgery leads to lagophthalmos (inability to close eyelid), predisposing the lower cornea to exposure and neuroparalytic ulceration.

  • The facial nerve (CN VII) controls the orbicularis oculi for eyelid closure.
  • Injury during parotid surgery impairs blink reflex and closure, leading to exposure keratopathy and ultimately a neuroparalytic corneal ulcer, particularly in the inferior half.
  • Symptoms include pain, redness, and visible corneal ulceration.

Related Important Points:

  • Unlike neurotrophic ulcers (due to sensory denervation via the trigeminal nerve), neuroparalytic ulcers are motor-related.
  • Treatment includes lubrication, moisture chambers, temporary tarsorrhaphy, and management of underlying nerve palsy.
  • Can lead to secondary infection if not promptly addressed.

Explanation of other options:

Neutrophic ulcer (Option A): Occurs due to trigeminal nerve dysfunction with loss of corneal sensation, not post-parotid surgery.

Severe dry eye (Option C): Causes punctate epitheliopathy, not classic inferior exposure ulcer.

Fungal corneal ulcer (Option D): Usually follows trauma with vegetative matter-clinical picture doesn't match.

questions.text: A regular contact lens user presents with complaints of severe pain, redness, photophobia and blurring of vision for more than two weeks, not responding to standard treatment. On examination, a paracentral ring-shaped lesion with stromal infiltrates and overlying epithelial defects is observed in the affected eye. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Contact lens wearers with ring-shaped stromal infiltrates, severe pain out of proportion to clinical findings, and poor response to routine therapy strongly suggest Acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • Acanthamoeba is a protozoan pathogen found in contaminated water, lens solutions, and poorly maintained contact lenses.
  • Ring infiltrate, perineural infiltrates, and severe pain (due to radial neuritis) are characteristic.
  • Often misdiagnosed initially due to a non-specific appearance, routine antibiotics are ineffective.

Related Important Points:

  • Diagnosis is often delayed due to resemblance to HSV or bacterial keratitis.
  • Culture on non-nutrient agar with E. coli overlay or confocal microscopy may confirm the diagnosis.
  • Treatment includes PHMB 0.02%, chlorhexidine 0.02%, and propamidine 0.1%, often in combination.

Explanation of other options:

Bacterial keratitis (Option A): Typically responds to standard fortified antibiotic therapy and lacks ring-shaped infiltrates.

Viral keratitis (Option C): Features include dendritic ulcers, reduced corneal sensation, not a ring infiltrate.

Fungal keratitis (Option D): History of vegetative trauma; often has feathery borders and satellite lesions.
